This is a cam I used to repair the door on my Kenmore Refrigerator Model 106.72003010. The right hand door would pop and click while opening and closing, and it would no longer close by itself. After some research, I bought a closing cam, part number WP67003638 or WP67003639 (mine was gray, but I can't find the part number now).

A phillips screw and three self-tapping metal screws hold the top hinge in place. When that's removed, the door lifts right off. I pulled the old part out and it didn't look damaged. Swapping in the new part and reassembling did not fix, so I pulled it apart and looked at it in more detail. The closing cam part fits into a socket in the door that has a matching cam to ride against the closing cam. On my door, the entire socket was rotating within the door. The expanding foam appeared to be all that was originally keeping it in place. While the closing cam itself is replaceable, the socket is part of the door, and is not individually replaceable. And a new door runs about half the cost of the whole refrigerator!

I was able to remove, clean, and reinstall the socket with a liberal application of gorilla glue. However, to keep the cam from twisting the socket while the glue dried, I printed this shim to lift the door just enough for the cams to avoid contact. When in place, the door is lifted by the height of the cam, and does not close automatically. Once the glue was fully cured, I slipped this cam out, and the door works like new. It's probably better than new, since gorilla glue should hold the socket better than the original insulating foam did.

Problem solved, and 3D printer cost fully justified!!!

Rainbow Color Library

Library to produce 2D array of RGB values scaled across an arbitrary size

This thing does not make a printable object. The output from this thing is primarily to demonstrate the utility of the colorArray() function. The colorArray() function produces a 2D array of RGB values that can be used in other projects.

Use

  • download the .scad file
  • move the file somewhere in your home directory: /home/MyUser/OpenSCAD/myLibraries/
  • Add the following line to one of your project files: use </home/MyUser/OpenSCAD/myLibraries/colors.scad>

Getting Help

  • use </path/to/colors.scad>
  • from within OpenScad help_colors() for a list of all modules
  • for help with a specific module help_colors("coloraArray");
  • rinse, repeat.

You are more than welcome to try and print this, but I made no attempt to make the objects properly manifold.

Aaron Ciuffo (Txoof)
Reach me at google mail: aaron dot ciuffo
https://www.thingiverse.com/txoof/about
released under GPL V3.0

Latest versions can be found at github:
https://github.com/txoof/OpenSCADColors

User Facing Functions

function colorArray

create an X by Y array of RGB values

accepts:

  • columns (integer): divisions of color wheel
  • rows (integer): number of itterations from origin
  • scaled (boolean): when true, return a value scaled by
    distance from origin
    returns:
  • X by Y array of RGB values

example:

  • myArray = colorArray(3, 3, scaled = false);
    for (row=[0:len(myArray)-1]) { //three iterations
    echo(colorArray[row]);
    }

  • ECHO: [[1, 0, 0], [1, 0, 0], [1, 0, 0]]
  • ECHO: [[0, 1, 0], [0, 1, 0], [0, 1, 0]]
  • ECHO: [[0, 0, 1], [0, 0, 1], [0, 0, 1]]

function chord

calculates chord length given a radius and angle

accepts:

  • r (real): radius of circle
  • angle (real): angle of segement
    returns:
  • length of chord (real)

example:

  • echo(chord(r = 10, angle = 60));
  • ECHO: 5.17638

function RGB

returns RGB value as 1D array of reals value between 0 an 1

accepts:

  • angle (real)
    returns:
  • RGB (array of real)

example:

  • echo(RGB(30))
  • ECHO: [1, 0.546691, 0]

funciton RGBScale

returns RGB value as 1D array of reals scaled by distance from origin (0-1)

accepts:

  • angle (real)
  • r (real): radius between 0-1
    returns:
  • RGB (array of real)

example:

  • echo(RGBScale(55, 1));
  • ECHO: [1, 0.941923, 0]
  • echo(RGBScale(55, 0.5));
  • ECHO: [1, 0.970961, 0.5]
  • echo(RGBScale(55, 0));
  • ECHO: [1, 1, 1]

Test Modules

module wheel

draws a color wheel

accepts:

  • segments (integer): number of segments to divide the wheel into
  • rings (integer): number of itterations
  • scaled (boolean): true - use color scaling
  • pixel (1D array): [x dimension, y dimension, z dimension] of elements

module objDemo

draws an array of objects using the colorArray() function to provide colors

accepts:

  • rows (integer): number of rows of objects
  • columns (integer): number of columns of objects
  • size (real): radius of objects
  • minQual (integer): minimum quality value to use
  • step (integer): steps to increase quality by
  • scaled (boolean): when true, use color scaling

module demoCyl

draw a hollow cylinder using the colorArray() function

accepts:

  • segments (integer): number of segments to divde cylinder into
  • layers (integer): number of layers
  • r (real): radius of cylinder
  • scaled (boolean): when true use color scaling

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt X GT2, Printrbot Simple V2

title: PrintrBot Simple X-axis GT2 Belt & Extension

description.text:
Replace the stock bed bearing support plywood with self-printed parts that allow you to print edge-to-edge on the existing bed with only $25 in additional parts.  This will increase print width from 100mm to 185mm (as shown by blue tape in photo)  
Optionally use with the Printrbot Simple Metal Print Bed For Build Volume Upgrade to increase print width to 275mm.
VITAMINS:

• 1 36" 8mm polished rod (McMaster 88625K67) - buy extras for other projects ;)
  • 4 3mm x 12mm flat head screws (McMaster 91294A132)
  • 1 PrintrBot GT2 Kit (belt and 2 pulleys - $20)
  • 2 608 (skate board) bearings (McMaster 5972K222)
    • Option 1 - increase to 275mm print width
    4a. 1 Printrbot Simple Metal Print Bed For Build Volume Upgrade ($30) Option 2 - increase to 400mm print width
    4b. 1 "Build your own bed" TOOLS

• Working CALIBRATED printer with at least 100x100 mm build volume
  • Calipers (i use cheapo "Neiko 01407A" from amazon)
  • 8.0mm and 2.5mm drill
  • Allen wrenches for 3mm socket, 3mm flat head and really small for GT2 pulley set screws
  • Heat gun or hair dryer
  • Hacksaw or 3.5" die-grinder with cutting wheel
    • PRELIMINARY (but not short) INSTRUCTIONS

NOTE - all prints were done by author using KISSlicer.

  • If you are printing on a stock simple print these parts WITHOUT SKIRT:
    1 simpleLeftEnd.stl
    1 simpleRightEnd.stl
    1 simpleRightBed.stl

  • If you are printing with a 150mm x 100mm build area print (skirt ok):
    1 leftEnd.stl
    1 rightEnd.stl
    1 rightBed.stl

  • For all printers print (skirt ok):
    1 MotorMountXGT2.stl (same as in thing 194686)
    2 BearingCap608.stl (same as in thing 194686)
    1 washers.stl
    1 rightSupport.stl
    1 leftSupport.stl

  • Clean plastic rod parts (leftEnd,RightEnd,RightBed) by running an 8mm drill into rod holes and a 2.5mm drill into all the tap holes. A small amount of material should come out but if you get a lot calibration or slicer setting aren't right

  • Take your new rod and cut in half to 2 18" pieces. I used a 3.5" die grinder with a cutting wheel, hack saw should work. After cutting sand the ends to remove any burrs. Note using 18" rods allows you to upgrade bed without making new rods. You can make rods shorter once you decide what you want

  • Test fit and adjust rod parts (leftEnd,RightEnd,RightBed) to the rods. In my case the rods didn't quite fit. So I used a heat gun to LIGHTLY warm the thin areas of the part until the rod fit - about 5 seconds on low. DO NOT heat so much that the part gets floppy. Assembles as follows: put leftEnd on the left end, slide rightBed onto the right end and slide down some then put rightEnd on right end. Once assembled remove the leftEnd while leaving other parts on the rods

  • Install both 608 bearings onto the MotorMountXGT2 using the BearingCap608 cap and a 12mm (?) cap screws.

  • Use the caliper to measure the distance between the top of the bed and the bottom of the bed bearing carrier in all four corners. Pick the shortest value then the subtract that number form the other three. The corner with the shortest value will be mounted with no washer and the value calculated above will determine the washers to use in the other corners. In my case the left and right sides were the same...

  • remove the bed, string and bed carrier and rods leaving the bearings attached to the bottom

  • remove the all right side screws, all bottom screws and screws into x motor plate on the left and top side. Remove motor screws

  • remove right side, bottom and x motor plate

  • test fit MotorMountXGT2, file/adjust as needed

  • position GT2 gear between 608 bearings then slide motor through MotorMountXGT2 into GT2. Screw motor to plate, tighten GT2 gear to shaft

  • put MotorMountXGT2 into position, reattach bottom and right side. screw everything together.

  • Cut GT2 belt in half. Feed between gear and bearing, around gear, then between other gear and bearing. Pull one end and slide into an end grabber.

  • Slide belt into other grabber as tight as possible. Thread 3mm cap screw into tap hole at end of the back rod on either left or right side. Tighten screw to add tension to belt - make sure to slide from part to stay square.

  • Position bed with wider screw/edge gap towards the back put a screw through the corner with no spacer (measured above) and screw in 1/4 of the way

  • put the other screw on the same side using the washer with the thicknes calculated for that location between the arm and the bed and screw in 1/4 of the way. Repeat for other 2 bed screws.

  • tighten all bed screws

  • Install the rightSupport and leftSupport using the screws holding the back support plate. The legs should angle forward. Note - lay the printer on the side so that the nuts don't drop out when you remove the screws.

  • In Repetitier edit printer settings -> printer shape and change X Max to 190 and Print Area Width to 190

  • In KissSlicer edit printer -> hardware and set bed size X to 185 and bed center to 95 (home position is approx 2.5mm off left edge of bed)

  • if you find that the printer stops at 100mm you will need to inform the FIRMWARE about the new limits. In the manual control tab of Repetier run "M208 x190" to increase the firmware limit. If it works run "M500" to save your new limits. You can also use Config->Firmware EEProm Configuration command to do the same thing
    • Try printing bigBox.stl to test the limits of your new bed using the VASE setting WITHOUT a skirt. Note - big box current goes around the back bed screws as I haven't got the flat head screws yet and I'm using cap screw which would hit the hot end That's all...

comments.text: Um - sorry to be sour grapes here, but - from your pictures I cannot conceive of what you're doing.  Clearly this involved a lot of time and effort on your part, and toward a worthy cause, but I'm afraid the photojournalism leaves me clueless.  Perhaps to someone who owns a Simple (or is otherwise well acquainted therewith) this makes some sense, but all the detail shots in the world won't likely portray the BIG PICTURE of what you're replacing with what!  Sorry, as I said, but I thought you might as well know.  Odds are I ain't the only one, but most would just cruise on without wasting their time telling you.  ...and - in case you're wondering - no, AAMOF, I'm not spatially challenged.  Quite the opposite, as bona fide testing has indicated.   ...and, I've been running a Pbot I built for a couple years now - just not a Simple.

comments.text: To extend the travel limits you need to send the M208 set axis travel command in repetier host.   Ie send "M208 x275".   After you have changed the values you can save them as power on defaults using the M500 command.   Its possible your firmware doesn't support the M208 command.  To test if you have the coommand run M503 - show current settings.  It should list the current values for M208 (ie M208 x100 y100 z100).  If there is no M208 in the output you will have to upgrade your firmware.  I also think there is a dialog in Repetier that lets you changes these values and save to EEProm which might be a little easier

comments.text:
YMMV, but be aware that the 88625K67 rod has a tolerance of plus/minus .013mm. The first one I tried must be at the high end of that range and is a tight fit with a lot of friction in the linear bearings, and popped a couple of ball bearings out and has machined grooves one the rod where there ball bearings ride. Not ideal.
My local MechE tells me that the 1265K64/1265K66/1265K67/1265K68 shaft is better for this application since its tolerance is plus 0/minus .005mm, however, it is considerably more expensive (approx 10x!).
I did follow your advice and bought extra rod, but haven't had an opportunity to test fit them yet. perhaps I got lucky and got some with a minus deviation as well. If more than 1 out of 10 works, it is still cheaper.

print_settings.Notes:: My printer has a 0.5mm nozzle and I prefer to use Slic3r 0.9.9. dev with the config file I have uploaded, as the blade prints as a single extrusion, which keeps the cookie cutter strong and the blade does not delaminate, like it sometimes does, if it is printed as 2 thinner walls.

title: Hogwarts House Banners from Cursed Child

description.text:
Hogwarts house flags from The Harry Potter Cursed Child Play.

Thanks for the help with these Dad :)

Printer:

Ecksbot ZA

Resolution:

0.25mm layer hight

Infill:

100%

Notes:

My printer has a 0.5mm nozzle and I prefer to use Slic3r 0.9.9. dev with the config file I have uploaded, as the blade prints as a single extrusion, which keeps the cookie cutter strong and the blade does not delaminate, like it sometimes does, if it is printed as 2 thinner walls.

I use the Cookie Cutter generator by Guru to generate the individual components of the various cookie cutters.

I use Netfabb Basic to position all the individual pieces of the cookie cutter and save them in their new positions.

I use Pronteface to compose the individual pieces and then export a single composite STL.

This is not what it looks like! Or maybe it is, if you like it that way. If you look from the top, you will see a heart though.
The thing was an actually an experiment to make a single walled vase with a thicker lip, but the curvy shap was a find too good to pass.

I printed this with Cura, 1mm wall, 0.8mm nozzle (you might get away with that setting without actually having a 0.8 nozzle installed), 0.4mm layer height, 6sec min layer time, 1.2mm bottom, no top and 'joris' enabled. (last two settings in expert). I rotated the curvy part towards the fan as you probably want the least defects there... :)

description.text:
I printed a 3D Marble Maze, and needed a marble for it, so I made one.

I've included two versions - one that is just a marble, the other designed to print without supports. The no support version is cut in 1/2 with the flat sides down, and a small pin to help align the two halves.

I've also included the OpenSCAD file I used to generate both models.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

90%

Notes:

I left supports at 'Doesn't Matter', because neither 'Yes' nor 'No' is correct either - but it does matter. The full sphere will need supports, the cut-in-half version does not.

I recommend a high infill, just to give it weight.

I did mine using the variable layer height function in Slic3r Prusa Edition - using 0.3mm layers for the pin and lower parts of the cut-in-half marble, and slowly reducing to 0.07 layers as it reaches the upper parts of the marble to give it a nice smooth finish all around.

description.text:
Replacement temperature control knob (thermostat) for a Maytag refrigerator. I suspect that it will work with various refrigerator makes and models because I've seen similar knobs on other refrigerators.

I don't know how this gets broken. Maybe getting hit by gallons of milk or something, but eventually the acrylic cracks and breaks then falls off.

You can print the basic model with the raised text and leave as is, or you can paint the numbers.

If paint isn't your thing, you can print the part with the insets and print the numbers separately in a different color then glue them in.

The one with the insets is a bit more difficult to print, but if you're up for a challenge, it's very rewarding.

You can test if your printer is capable of producing a print with the tolerances necessary to fit the refrigerator by printing the SizeTest. You can test the inset by printing the InsetTest.

No supports are needed. There are some overhangs on the bottom, but it's not in a place that will be visible. Your printer should be able to bridge.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm (.10mm for the numbers)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Set your walls to 2.0mm, and it shouldn't need much infill. If you do end up with infill, you probably want concentric, and set it to 100%. There isn't a lot of plastic on this part, so 100% infill is fine.

Use .10mm layer resolution for everything if you can stand waiting. You'll get better quality, less cleanup, and easier assembly.

If you print the numbers, put them all on the plate, but use the "Print one at a time" option to reduce the retraction (and cleanup required).

If you decide to paint, depending on your brush technique, you might have better results rolling the numbers across the paint.

I used Super Glue to glue the numbers in. Tip: You only glue one surface when using Super Glue. I put super glue on a coated paper plate, dipped the number in, then inserted and held for a few seconds.

title: Prusa I3 MK2 Bed Level Test Print

description.text:
This is to test the bed levelling on the Prusa I3 MK2, I recently discovered that the probe doesn't in fact adjust for "unflat" beds even though it's meant to and this print will help check for inconsistencies.

Just remember to stop the print after the first layer.

Here is a link to my video where I do this print a few times and adjust my settings according ot the results: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=byiWdKYhiGI&feature=youtu.be

comments.text: Thank you for the file. Used it this morning to tweak my first layer. My bed is lower on the right side and the mesh leveling seems to have no effect on that. First I printed the PIND tool from Nerdville, it helped me to reduce my Z Adjust to -150 instead of -680 so that was a good step already and then with your file and playing with the manual bed leveling, it turned out that even -50 for the right side was not enough so I used a command to force it to -100 like explained here: http://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/original-prusa-i3-mk2-f23/help-fine-calibrating-with-bed-level-correct--t2700.html

description.text:
Another Y-Belt Tensioner for the Anet A8 printer. It is a little bit inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1959208 .
It uses a M4 Hex-Head Screw for tensioning and a plate to spread the pressure evenly. The front plate and the sliders are screwed together with M3 countersunk bolts (min length 8mm, max length 15mm).
The ball bearings are kept at distance to the sliders with a small distance ring.

No Supports are needed. The knurled screw has one 0.2mm Layer which acts as support for the hole (bridged) and must be broke out after printing.

My microphone and my headphones have separate cables since they are separate units. I wanted to be able to keep the two cables together to make cable management less of a headache since my pug puppy keeps getting tangled in the cables when I'm playing iRacing, so I came up with these little S-shaped clips to do just that. The big side is designed for a 3.75mm cable, the small side for a 2.5mm cable. Those cable sizes are the same as a standard USB cable and the smaller headphone cable size, like the cable that comes with earbuds.

description.text: This wrench adapter fits a Camco 02142 or similar water heater element with a 1.5" hex head. It can be turned with a 13/16" wrench. I made this to facilitate installing a heater element through the wall of an ice chest, to make a DIY sous vide cooker. The ice chest has inner and outer walls, separated by foam. I drilled a 1.25" hole through both walls, enlarged the outer hole to 2" diameter, scraped away the foam insulation around the hole, and installed the heater element through the wall using a plastic conduit nut sized for 1" conduit, such as Grainger item 2DZG8 (goo.gl/YLgPTS), or Thomas & Betts Steel City BU503-1 plastic bushing. Print with 100% infill and supports. Print with the 13/16" hex stud down and use supports.

In one of my aircrafts I have to detatch the APM to plug or unplug any of the peripherials. The usual solution could be i.e. velcro fix the APM, but I was afraid that this would influence the board alignment.
Therefore I designed this cradle. It can be attached to the aircraft permanently and holds the APM precisely in a defined reference positon. The APM is fixed in the cradle with a cable tie.

One of Nintendo's greatest hits in a tiny size! This is truly a wee Wii. Comes with most of the good accessories. Quite a simple print, the only catch is how you assemble the body:

  1. Print Body.stl and plug.stl in the body color, but do blue_plate.stl in blue.
  2. Slide blue_plate.stl into the body so that it blanks out the DVD slot
  3. insert plug into body and glue into place - this will hold the blue_plate in place, and give you that "blue LED is lit up" look.

Too lazy to print your own? Buy one form our store - http://store.rabbitengineering.com

author: IKOEQJ

description.text:
I built one of the Ikea LACK enclosures for my printer. I wanted to mount a 360W power supply under the printer. These parts are what I used to mount it.

I used a hole saw to drill two 1.5" holes through the lower table, one at the front and one at the back. I then mounted the power supply so that the exhaust blows up through the hole in the front and the power supply cables go up through the other.

I also used the power cable hole for a USB cable and I have a Raspberry Pi mounted on the underside of the printer stand as well.

I have the exhaust grill setup so that it blows towards the side wall. The reason I have the exhaust blowing into the enclosure is to help add warmth inside the case for printing ABS. I also have an exhaust fan on a temperature controller for keeping it from getting too hot inside the enclosure.

Honestly, the power supply doesn't seem to really add much heat to the enclosure.

You will need 4 of the power supply mounts and one of each of the other two parts.

author: IKOEQJ

description.text:
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
WARNING! Don't make this... yet.
This plan worked completely fine while printing PLA and heating the bed to 65'C. But, when I started printing PETG with a heat bed at 85'C, the resistance in the bolt was too much, warmed up the connector and melted the PLA. Thankfully, I noticed and avoided a short.
I'm currently awaiting banana plug hardware and will modify the setup to accomodate.
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

After moving my power supply under my lack table and adding a cover with a power switch, I wanted an above-table disconnect for the printer as well as a real time volt meter for the power lines coming up through the table.

I simply used M4 bolts as the power studs and simple Chinese voltmeters for the displays.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/391701932930

You may notice a 5V hole on the side. I'm working on adding a usb power connector on that side, but I'm working out exactly how I want to handle that.

comments.text: Why are you wiring it this way and with such thick cables? Checking voltage can be done with 20 awg and smaller and it'd be simple to throw in a properly rated on/off OR a 2 channel relay.
comments.author: alanminor

comments.text: Thanks for commenting.  It reminded me that I still need to update this.  The power supply is under the lack table with a switch and the input wires are coming up through the table.  The two sets of connections you see are both outputs.  One to the main board, the other to the Mosfet.  As wired, it's both a shock and a fire danger.  Don't do it.  I've since, redone this to use banana posts.  I just need to upload the updated stls and take new pictures.  The volt meter wires are 20awg and hidden inside the box.
comments.author: alanminor

description.text:
The Regalux Clip!

Yeah, basically it's just a clip.

Unfortunately I don't have an Ikea close to my home to build a dry box for my filament.
So I decided to check out the local hardware strores and found this box from Regalux.
I suppose those boxes are not available worldwide, but maybe someone finds this clip helpful, too.

I used "bummsters" great set for filament dry boxes.
As you might notice, I used some window seal to keep the box airtight.
For now this works very well for me.
Happy printing!

description.text:
A case to store your Joy-Con controllers in for travel to keep them safe, or when not using them to keep the dust off of them. Or whatever else you want.

Drop your Joy-Cons into the slots, buttons side up, and slide the lid into the groove to cover them up.

As I do not own a Switch yet, I have not printed and tested these myself; I would greatly appreciate it if someone who owns Joy-Cons could see how well this case fits them. When I get my own Switch and Joy-Cons, I'll edit this Thing with pictures of my print and controllers.

Inventor parts included if you would like to edit the box at all.

My kids wanted stands for their Starwars action figures because they kept tipping over. I planned on just making some simple stands but my son really wanted the rebel or empire symbol on them so I put it on the base. He was not happy with that, he wanted it displayed a lot bigger behind the character. I thought it was a bad idea but I did it anyways to make him happy and in the end it turned out looking pretty good!

Print out the base and insert a 3/32" diameter. x 1/2" long dowel pin in to the hole to hold the action figure in place. You can add super glue to the pin if you have any issues with it falling out. I purchased the dowel pins at a local hardware store but they could also be found here:
https://www.mcmaster.com/#98381a438/=16m0xvo

The symbol simply inserts in to the slot in the back of the stand. The end is tapered so it locks into place pretty well but if you have any issues with it coming out just add super glue. I made a version without the symbol slot as well.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

No

title: IEC320 fuesed and switched Inlet Holder

description.text:
Case for IEC320 C14 switched and fused Inlet.

The inlet part is pushed in and locked with four notches. The fit is very tight, so it will be securely trapped in the case. You will barely get it out again.

In the bottom is a tunnel for an cable tie for strain relief.

I also added a lid. Witch is necessary for reliable insulation if the Case is mounted on conductive surfaces (including coated metal). I am using it on wood without the lid.

You can minimize height slightly by scaling down in z direction in your slicer.

If you want to use countersink screws use the conical washers.

!!!Attention!!! This part is intended for power line connection. So be care full. If you don't know exactly what you are doing ask someone who knows. You are using this design on your own risk! If you don't agree with this term, don't use this design!

=> This Part is used in my Prusa i3 Master Rework

Printer:

Sintron Prusa i3

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

30%

Notes:

If you want to fine tune the fit, scaling won't help you much. Instead try playing with the extrusion rate, or tell the slicer you are using a 0.5mm nozzle, while you heaving a 0.4mm nozzle on the printer.

Solder the connections according to the pictures. The wires must be soldered in the holes of the pins not just to the side. Use shrink tubing and a cable tie for strain relief as shown in the pictures.

A simple reference panel to remind you which way the nuts need to be spun to level your print bed. I have attached STLs for left and right handed threads.

Right handed threads will be 'Up-Down' or 'Close-Open'.

It's really up to you which you use and how you think about it.

Generally you will probably want 'Up-Down', especially if using a Wanhao Duplicator i3 like myself.

Apologies if I have gotten any of this wrong - I rushed to finish this on my break.

comments.author: sdub76

description.text:
I give you the largest project I've designed to date. Projects with Moving parts and lot of them are not simple! It's final design is my version #4 of just under a year of work. Don't let it's simple looks fool you, it was a lot of work. I think it has some issue that may be reworked here and there but I needed to remember that many people can't print items larger than my chosen size of the "Deck Plate" part. I would like a wider wheel base which would give better stability. I was amazed of how much weight this thing could accommodate, and the more weight on it the more stable it was.

The Pipe is standard 1/2" PVC schedule 40 white. You can remove all those nasty printing on the pipe with a small wire brush or scrape back and forth with a pocket knife.
To attach all items to the pipes. I drilled a small pilot hole near the connecting base and and screwed a screw in that goes through the pvc pipe and into the 15.3mm knobs that stick up. You could use pvc glue if you like but I don't know how PLA and that glue interact.
Pictures are of my baby after a full day's use. The handle and the wheels are printed in Ninja flex but don't need to be. First persons reactions were though, "Ooh the handle feels nice.." and it rolls on wood floors with a very soft and quiet sound. FYI I had to tilt the top section to make it stand up for the solo picture but during normal use it does not slouch like that. It took me a few tries to jam it in that configuration for the picture else the slide goes down as intended.

For the axles I used the bolts that come with the eSun Filament rolls. I put the "Wheel Base" into a vice and pushed the nut and the bolt head into the axle locations with my 30 watt soldering iron. In a min or two they were seated perfectly in place.

2 stranded ABEC 8mm Bearings (used in roller blades) pop into each of the 2 wheels. (total of 4) Here is a link to some but any or the cheapest once you find will be super. https://www.amazon.com/Generic-Precision-Bearing-Skateboard-Longboard/dp/B00ZSKWZZK

I printed everything with 7 shells at .25mm using a .4 nozzle with 15% fill and it's very sturdy!
Handle,TopBar, Wheel, Wheelbase need to be printed with supports. See the last picture for the print orientations that I used. FrontLeg, and Deck Plate does not need supports.

My lower PVC Pipes are about 18" (457mm) long. The upper ones can be a bit longer based on your height. I recommend printing the lower parts, putting together and then measuring where you think it feel comfortable.

If you want modifications or the source files for a remix, let me know and formats you can use as I designed this with Solid works.
NOTE: The deck part didn't finish printing on my version in the pictures, but, enough of it printed for me to assemble and actually use.

This is a magnetic hex bit holder. You will need 5 8mm diameter x 2mm thick neodymium magnets. Also you will need to pause your print at approximately 3.1mm to insert the magnets.

For an exhibition I need a column that hides a monitor to show an endless loop of a video.

The idea was to create a system that is mutable. Here in the pictures you see a three-cornered column. But you could build a square one with the parts too - or just a zigzag wall.
All you need are the printed hinge-joints, some aluminium tubes (20/1 mm), panels and screws (3mm - the length depending on the thickness of you panels).
And there are connectors if you want to stack the panels, as well as plugs to close the tubes or to use as feet.

My panels are 60 x 100 cm so I took 6 pieces of 1 m aluminium pipe. As I wanted to add the monitor, I designed one side as a door to have access to the technik - simple printed hinges did the job.

Print all with 3 shells and at least 65% Infill. Use ABS.
The assemble.stl is to view only - as an example.
I added the FreeCad-files.

Update: A picture from the opening of our ehibition (the column painted white)

This is an idealized B-form DNA duplex surface representation with a G-C base pair exposed. This helps illustrate the major and minor grooves, and helps to visualize how the nucleobases are involved in stacking within the duplex.

Files need to be scaled. Pictures are versions printed at 400%. Orientation will depend largely on your printer and what you can get away with for overhang angles. Certainly needs supports.

To put the base pair in it is easiest to clip the protruding cylinders from the sugar on one side just a bit and stick that side in second.

remixed_from.author: gonilsen
remixed_from.title: Measuring clock holder for Prusa I3

description.text:
The original was nearly perfect, except that the indicator hole was too small, and the gap to tighten it down was non-existent when I printed. I increased the gap to 1mm, and made two versions for different hole sizes. The 10mm was just a tad too large for my gauge, so I made a 9.5mm version as well.

As you can see, this still didn't work for my gauge. It's leg was too short to touch the build plate. I made a Low Rider version that does work though. The link for it is down below. I also added the Fusion 360 source files for those that want to customize it more.

Don't use this as your primary source of leveling. I'd recommend using the feeler gauge/paper method to get it pretty closed, then use this to fine tune it. Trust me, it'll save you a ton of time. It uses an M3x15-20mm bolt and M3 nut. I only had 20mm bolts, but 15mm should be plenty.

Also, this mount is for dials that do not have the back plate with mounting holes (for traditional use). If yours has the mounting holes on the back, there are plenty of other great mounts already made on thingiverse.

Low Rider Dial Indicator Mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2153312

Cheers!

remixed_from.author: Gear_Down_For_What
remixed_from.title: Modular Robotic Arm, Hinge Joint, No Hardware

description.text:
Updates!

6/27/17- Wrote program for controlling robot with potentiometers using the potentiometer setup from the collection. Check it out!
6/4/17- Video by Erica_86 https://youtu.be/XhCFEov6GUg
5/21/17- Uploaded a redesigned version of this, EZER
5/7/17- Updated Arduino Program.
5/6/17 - New youtube video https://youtu.be/8H3fbxzmF9w
4/27/17- Designed another gearbox for this! 66:1
4/9/17- Designed a EE Gripper.
4/6/17-Added the End Effector holder from my modular robotic arm "thing" to this "thing" so you don't have to download both "things".
3/26/17- Uploaded Arduino sketch that i have been controlling this with. I have improved this by making it do calculations when the joint has arrived at a point, and calculating all the angles it has to move to before it begins moving. when using XYZ coordinates it will move in a straight line. The homing is done by just moving the joint to its max left position then max right so the stepper will skip steps until its centered. i used 1/4 stepping on my stepper driver for this.
3/18/17- Uploaded New Rotating Base
3/14/17- Uploaded the Arduino Program that I'm using to control this. it uses inverse kinematics to determine the position of J3 from XYZ.
3/12/17- V3 parts - Chamfered the hole that the pins fit into so there isn't extra material from bridging that needs removal.
3/9/17- V2 - Fixed issues with too much clearance between the ring gears and ring holders. Made all of the ring holders .1mm smaller, leaving .1 of clearance between the ring gear and ring holder.

Where's Everything Else???

https://www.thingiverse.com/Gear_Down_For_What/collections/robotic-arm
In This Collection you will find:
  • All other related parts for this project
  • Future Updates to this Project
  • All User Submitted Remix's
  • Click that watch button to get notifications on future uploads!

Special Instructions For The Gearbox(s):

1.) Pick your favorite gearbox from the collection
2.) Print out all 4 ring gears, the "4 Module planet gears", the "One piece sun" and "Sun gear #4"

  • The Gearboxes that are to be used with this joint are located in the "Robotic Arm" collection.
  • Don't get confused by other similar gearboxes that I have made, if they are compatible, they will be listed in the collection, link is above.
    • The gearboxes are used to support the joint, like emmets gear bearing, but they also drive the joint, so they are necessary!

Running the gearbox without it pressed into the arm is a good way to wear it in so it doesn't rob torque from your stepper, but it can also take the the planet gears out of alignment if the rings open up and skip a gear. if the gears aren't arranged as pictured above the gearbox will wear itself out rather quickly.

A and B? (Compatibility)

  • In the above picture, the parts called "bottom" are a "B" style connection, and the parts labeled "top" are an "A" Style connection.
  • The End Effector Holder is a "B" style connection.
  • Connections with a stepper motor mount are considered "A" Style connections.
  • It's an unavoidable compatibility problem that arose from the recent simplification of the design. Opposite's attract, "A" style connections only mate with "B" style connections and "B" style connections only mate with "A" style connections.

Required Hardware

  • (2) 6/32's or 4mm bolts 55mm long (2 Per Joint)
  • (4) short 3mm bolts to hold the stepper motor in place (4 Per Stepper)

Drive motors

  • Nema 17 for all
  • Don't buy cheap Nema 17 motors, they will get hot and melt the gears!

Bendy Bend Bend:

This arm rotates 230 degrees before colliding with itself in the cad program but it is actually more like 229 degrees real life.

Other Important Info:

Electronics, Firmware?!?
  • Program that I use is here: https://github.com/GearDownForWhat/RobotArm
  • I run this on an Arduino DUE with a CNC shield and DRV8825 Stepper drivers, Arduino MEGA "might" also work for this.
  • Arduino Due A000062
  • CNC Shield Expansion Board with drv8825 Stepper Motor Drivers
  • Nema 17 Steppers I used for J0 and J1
  • Smaller (cheaper) Steppers and Optional Wires For Cheaper and Smaller Steppers
CAD Files??
  • I Included the Fusion 360 Project and CAD .STEP files with this.
  • Feel free to create your own modifications and parts for this project, and if you do, make sure you create a remix and upload them, then I'll add them to my main collection so the whole community can share them! Thanks!
Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! (make? :0) Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel

Gear Down For What?

We are a participant in the Amazon Services LLC Associates Program, an affiliate advertising program designed to provide a means for us to earn fees by linking to Amazon.com and affiliated sites.

This is a sword i printed for my kid for his Assassin costume. The sword is based on the this concept art https://www.pinterest.com/pin/532198880952207829/ and modified according to my kids wishes. I modeled it in Maya and detailed it in Zbrush. The sword is split in half (and each half into 3 pieces) and has a channel running along the lenght to fit bent piece of M4 threaded rod for strenght. I glued the pieces and threaded rod with epoxy glue and painted it with silver and acrylic paints. Parts were printed on Prusa i3 MK2 on 0.35mm layer thickness for speed. I could print on less and get better details but i kinda like the effects of layers, it looks like some sort of etching.. :)

I made a sheat for the sword from leather (draw template, cut, puncheh holes and sawed itd, painted..), printed Assasins Creed buckle and assambled the whole "holster" to hold the sword..

There are some other printed things on the costume, like raven badges, rivets, buckles, rings, but this are only the files for the sword.

title: Printrbot Simple Adjustable Spool Stand / Coaster

description.text:
This is a modified version of Ramai's "Spool holder, Adjustable, from PB design." Requires 4 skateboard bearings. If you are not limited to a 4x4 bed, then you may consider his design instead.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:178862 I wanted to be able to print this coaster on a smaller printer. Mine is a Printrbot Simple and it only prints 4x4x4. I'm sure the design can be improved but I made these modifications in under 2 hours. I put screw holes in the fins and the coaster so you could securely attach the fins if needed. For now my fins are holding just by melting some of the PLA with a lighter and sticking the fin to the coaster. I had to melt some raw filament in some of the cracks between the fin and coaster, but they seem to be holding. I have made several successful prints with it.

Printed at:
  • M201 X700 Y700 Z30 E10000
  • M203 X60 Y60 Z2.00 E14.00
  • Layer Hight 0.3
  • Make sure you bed is warm (ABS users) or make sure your painter's tape is firmly secured to bed (PLA users), as this print tends to bow up otherwise. Due to this, I recommend using the fan as little as possible!
    • Specs:
  • Minimum width is 60mm
  • Max width is 100mm
    • Assembly:
  • Attach skateboard bearings to coaster before attaching fins so you don't accidentally snap them off.
  • Attach fins to coaster with screws or melted PLA.
    • **Your printer needs to be fine tuned before attempting this print.

title: Filament holder with weight sensor

description.text:
This is a filament holder with a load cell integrated to weigh the filament spool. I thought this would be a fun way to weigh the filament to ensure I have enough for a print without having to resort to a scale. Assembly BOM, tools required and assembly comments are noted at the bottom.

Summary:
Pros
It works. I've tested it on several prints and the load cell is about +/- 0.05 lbs. This will depend on how well you've calibrated the load cell.

Cons
1) Need help with this... if I power cycle the load sensor PCB which I purchased from Spark Fun, the calibration and tare weight are not saved. I'm not very good with software so I don't know how to change the code which was pre-loaded in the PCB so its saves these settings.
2) Because of this issue, I just never turn it "off".
3) Using a load cell with range closer to the full weight of the filament (typical 2kg) would be better. Load cells like most sensors offers sense errors of some percentage based on full scale. In this case, its a 10 kg load cell. This means the error is a bit higher than say a load cell that's at 4 kg. But as stated, I still get +/- 0.05 lbs so that's good enough for me.

Assembly BOM:
Qty 1: Spark Fun Open Scale (SEN - 13261)
Qty 1: Spark Fun Load Cell 10 kg, Straight Bar (SEN - 13329 ROHS)
Qty 3: McMaster Carr 6389K228
Qty 4: McMaster Carr 2515T180 (Optional if you want the leveling feet)
Qty 2: M5 x 25mm L Socket Cap Head screw
Qty 3: M4 x 16mm L Flat Head Socket Cap Head screw
Qty 4: M3 x 10 mm Pan Head Philips screw
Qty 1: USB to mini-B USB cable

Tools:
M4 Tap
M3 Tap
5/16 - 18 Tap
Wire stripper for 0.8 mm wire (Super fragile, be gentle when stripping back insulation)

Software:
Serial Port Communicator - Options below
1) Arduino IDE serial port communicator
2) Tera Term (This is my preference) Go to this link for a tutorial from Spark Fun. This site will have a link to download.
https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/terminal-basics/tera-term-windows

Assembly Tips:
1) When mounting the load cell, the M4 side of load cell will be on the filament side. You'll see a sticker at the of the load cell with an arrow. Make sure its pointing up, otherwise you get a negative weight reading.
2) Practice cutting insulation back on the load cell wires before cutting to length. Take your time, you can easily cut the conductor along with the insulation.
3) Sorry for making you guys tap threads :(

Using Spark fun load cell:
Go to this site for tutorial on the open scale PCB, very useful.
https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/openscale-applications-and-hookup-guide?_ga=1.116997955.477175760.1487732422

For setting tare weight (Setting weight to be Zero with an empty filament spool), use your most often used empty spool. I'm guessing most filament spools will be pretty close in weight, using your most often used spool ensures you have the best weight info most of the time.

Feed back for improvements are welcome.

title: Lulzbot Taz X Belt Tensioning System

description.text:
I built my Taz to the original factory spec's, but I was disappointed with the tensioning system for the X and Y axes. After playing with a few designs, this one worked the best allows for relatively easy adjustment. The holes are sized for Dodge Fastener 3.8mm long, M3x0.5mm threaded heatset inserts because I had them on hand. This design uses the following hardware: 9x 3.8mm M3x0.5mm heatset inserts
8x 10mm M3 button head cap screws
1x 60mm M3 socket head cap screw
5x M3 washers To adjust, simply remove the extruder mount to expose the 4 screws that hold the sliders to the carriage. Loosen the 4 screws slightly, then adjust your belt tension using the 60mm screw. Once adjusted, tighten the screws to lock everything back in place. **Note - The X Carriage has not only been modified to include the adjustment slot, but I have also changed the cable management setup. This version has two clips on top which are identical to the filament guide pieces. I just printed an extra filament tube holder and zip-tied it to my cable assembly.
Print at high (90-95%) infill for robust parts. Mine were made in ABS at 0.20mm layer height with 1 perimeter and 4 top and bottom shells, 95% infill.

Print with TPU

I made a new base for the robot arm to attach a Arduino Nano on a Shield. You can directly atttach the servo motors on the shield, because it has got all the power and ground pins directly at every signal pin. This makes wiring much easyer. Also there is more weight on the ground plate so that the robot arm is more stable while moving

Also I added two knobs for play and pause that fit to my micro switches I used.

And I used smaller 6mm trimmer potentionmeters so I hat to make some adapters that I added here, too. Print more of them at once so that the small axles can cool down before the next layer is added. So they will not bend while printing. There is also a split verion that is printed 90° turned which also could work.

Another thing I added are printable round servo wheels, my servos didn't come with fitting parts.

description.text:
This is a plaque of the ideal layer heights for the MP Select Mini.
It has recesses on the back side for 2 Harbor Freight magnets.
A 10 pack of Harbor Freight magnets is Item Number 67488.

I apologize for the quality of the picture, the camera wasn't cooperating with me.

Edit: The last entry had a typo.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.0875

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a sharpie to color the lettering but since printing one I learned that the printer can be paused by editing the G-Code to add the M600 command.
I would use the layers view of Cura to find the layer where I wanted to change colors then insert a line before that layer with M600.

I use Notepad2 to search for LAYER:n where n is the number of the layer where the filament change is to take place.

When the file is run the printer will pause just as if you selected pause from the jog dial, just make rotate the jog dial to the unpause positon and select it after you have changed the filament.

You will want to purge the old color by pushing the filament by hand until the new color come through.

Attaching to the printer

The plaque can be attached using what ever method you wish but as described above Harbor Freight magnets can be used.

DesignSpark

I used a free program called DesignSpark to create this plaque.
This program is provided by RS Components/Allied Electronics and is a lite version of Space Claim.

In order to add text I used the method of dimensioning a line, editing the text and font then projecting it on to the object. It usually takes selecting the project icon twice.

Hide the annotation plane then you can use the pull tool to extrude each character of text in or out as desired.

Hopefully future versions will include adding test directly but for now that's quickest way to do it without using a separate CAD program.

I included the RSDOC file for anyone using DesignSpark.

title: Expanding Sewing Gauge (Simflex Inspired) for Measuring Pleats and Button Holes

description.text:
This is an expanding gauge. It always shows equal spacing between its points. Ideal for marking buttonhole, pleats, or other repeating patterns.

The number of points is up to you. 8 or 10 are commonly used.

All parts are printed and then snapped together - nothing else is required.

Please post photos of your makes - Its cool to see what you print + I like to learn how people's print settings affect my designs.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.32 layers (for faster printing)

Infill:

60%

Notes:

All parts tested on my printer using layers around 0.3mm in height. 50 or 60% infill recommended for strength.

If the objects have been rotated onto their edges by the software, place them flat side down on the print bed in your slicer.

Instructions - Print and Assembley

(1) Decide how many points you will need (X) and print 'arm three' X times
(2) Print the 9mm connector set twice as many times (X multipled by 2)
(3) Print 'arm one' X times -1
(4) Print one 4mm connector peg for each 'arm one'
(5) Print 'arm two' X times -1
(6) Print four of the 3mm washers

For an 8 point gauge, your parts list will be:
8x arm three
16x 9mm connector set
7x arm one
7x 4mm connector peg
7x arm two
4x 3mm washers

Assembly:

The push fit connectors will be tight in the holes on the arms, this is normal. Rotate them a few times to bed them in before moving to the next one.

The octagonal peg parts of the connectors are also tight. They not designed to be removable. Insert them gently with pliers, a press, a vice, or gentle taps with a hammer.

(1) First set of three arms:

Take an arm three, an arm one, two 3mm washers and a 9mm connector set.

(1a) Connecting arms three and one:

Arm three goes at the bottom. Arm one goes on top, with the round peg facing up.
Put one of the round holes of arm one over the top of the round hole on arm three.
Put a 3mm washer on top. Connect the parts with a 9mm connector set.

(1b) Adding arm two:

Press the central round hole of arm two onto the round peg of arm one. Connect with a 4mm peg.
Put an end circular hole of arm two over the slot in arm three. Use a 3mm washer inbetween. Connect with a 9mm connector set.

(2) Intermediate sets of three arms:

Use this procedure for all arms other than the beginning and end sets - which need washers.

(2a) Connecting arms one and two:

Connect a set of arms one and two using the central hole and peg, and a 4mm peg connector

(2b) Connecting arm three to the new arm one and previous arm two:

Line up the circular hole of arm three under a circular hole of arm one. Place the free end of arm two from the previous set on top. Connect using a 9mm connector set.

(2c) Connecting arm three to new arm two and previous arm one:

Line up the slot in arm three under the free circular hole in arm one from the previous set. Place the a circular hole of arm two on top. Connect with a 9mm connector set.

(3) Adding the end arm (the extra arm three)

Well done, you now only need to add the last arm three to complete your gauge.

(3a) Connecting arm three to the free end of the previous arm two:

Put your last arm three on the bottom. Line up a 3mm washer over the round hole. Line the free end of the previous arm two over the washer. Connect with a 9mm connector set.

(3b) Connecting the end arm three to the previous arm one:

Line up the slot in arm three under the free circular hole in the previous arm one. Line a washer up over the top. Connect with a 9mm connector set.

(4) Enjoy! Feel free to add comments and post pictures of your makes.

description.text:
Remixed this to fit on the Monoprice Select Mini bed which isn't quite large enough for the original. This was a pretty beefy mount to begin with, so i cut a few speed holes to save filament/time.

I printed in PETG and it's plenty strong enough to mount this behind the TV now.

Update: Added steam-link-mount-MPSM_VESA100.STL.stl I moved the screw hole a bit to put this back at 100mm spacing.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2625

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Not much infill needed, I printed using 4 walls, top and bottom layers. Support is needed for the overhang above the DC jack and the edges that grip the back of the link.

On the MP Select mini, i used a single line of skirt, just to purge the extruder before the print. There's not much room on the print bed for a brim, so make sure you have good enough adhesion to prevent a part this large from warping upwards at the corners. I was OK using glass/PEI @ about 70 degrees bed temp.

description.text:
This customizer friendly thing enables you to create a rock like thing... There's no science here, a little fun and just some simple OpenSCAD.

Thanks!

How to make a rock.

The first thing to do in generating a rock is to start somewhere. I decided to start with a sphere. For a while I was trying to understand how to manipulate a primitive sphere, but then I came across this blog post about creating organic shapes.

I was resolved to try to create a simple sphere with hull. Which proved a bit difficult, but I decided to brute force it, so if my math's a bit contrived, that is why. But eventually I got there! You can see this sphere in customizer by setting the deformation and skew to 0.

It's a lot like a sphere, but has extra poly's connecting the vertices, which is fine. According to the blog, using sphere's is wize, but I didnt see much difference between cubes and spheres. Either way, the hull creates a poly around the points!

With that, I just had to add some randomization to make the object less uniform, and I had my rock.

Really great story. I know.

title: Improved SN04 bracket for Anet A8

description.text:
My SN04 autolevel sensor arrived, so I figured I'd hook it up. I bought a bare sensor so I didn't have Anet's mounting bracket.

I printed off both versions of pparsniak's sensor bracket. The version with mounting pillars fouled with my X belt retainers (I'm not using the stock ones) and I felt the version without the pillars couldn't be screwed securely enough to the printer without warping it. So I did my own take on their bracket design.

This design uses pins which stick into the holes on the back of the SC8UU bearing holders, and positively locate the bracket on the printer carriage. It also rests on the shoulders of the bearings instead of the top, which puts the bracket slightly closer to the nozzle and allows the plate to be made thicker and stiffer.

To secure the plate to the printer, I'm using two of the spare flat head M3x30 screws that came with the printer, they screw into tapped holes that are provided on the printer's X carriage. To attach the sensor, I'm using M3x20 pan head screws and nuts.

Assuming you're using Marlin or Skynet firmware, you'll want to use the following offset settings in your configuration.h file:

X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 18
Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 55

A version is provided which has pillars which extend between the X carriage at the mounting holes and the bracket. The pillars are 1mm short, this is to make up for tolerance in the height of the printed pillars and the bearings - fill the extra space with M3 washers as needed. Note that I haven't printed or used the design with pillars, so print at your own risk :)

OpenSCAD source files are attached. This is the first thing I've designed in that software so it's a bit of a mess :)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Sliced in Slic3r.

Used PLA filament that came with the A8.
Infill was 30% rectilinear infill, and rectilinear top/bottom layers were used.
3 top/bottom layers and 3 perimeter layers.
Printed at 50mm/sec.

description.text:
Here's a quick kitchen hack that keeps garbage bags from falling into the can. I designed these little knobs in Autodesk Fusion 360 that will hold our drawstrings on the bags. This keeps the bag neat and tidy until it's time to take the garbage out.

My How-To Video: https://youtu.be/LlVicAR42HE

Fusion 360 Model: http://a360.co/2mR8Q3X

Project Steps:

  • We need a glue stick, lighter, and our 3d printed knobs.
  • Once we glue these to the can, we'll be done.
  • The first step is to get a bag and push it down into the bottom of the can.
  • Then pull out the drawstrings so we'll know where to mount the knobs.
  • Now we can heat up our gluestick and apply a good amount to the knob.
  • Locate approximately where it goes and... stick it onto the can.
  • Once the glue cools, repeat this for the other side.

And we're done... how easy was that?

Just in case you wanted to know what kind of garbage bags I used, these are 13 gallon drawstring bags from Walmart.

Inspired by Grant Thompson "The King of Random"

description.text:
Have you ever tried to disconnect the yellow connector part from a Medela breast pump set when your hands were soapy? I have, and it's not fun. These parts can be a bear to get apart.

I'm surprised that Medela doesn't include a wrench to disassemble these parts. Fortunately, I was able to easily model a wrench and it has been working great for the past month or so. This version is also compatible with the Maymom brand connectors which I purchased on accident.

Anywho, it's an easy print and your thumbs will thank you for it.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iclqenwW9AC
I created this small handle and base for making stamps. The 2nd piece I created for the stamping image is the Pi symbol (reversed for stamping purposes) which is another STL file in my things. However, this can be used for any other stamp or handle for an object needing a knob or handle.

Dust can settle on your filament rolls and potentially end up clogging your nozzles. This is a filament dust filter specifically for the Makerbot Replicator 2X and unlike others does not take up space on the extruders. The filter blocks have been specially designed in that they can be removed for cleaning without unloading the filament. They are also designed so they cannot "accidently" work loose from the filament. The tube support assembly clips together with a press fit and then slots securely into the Rep2X tube supports. You can see a render of the assembly at http://youtu.be/t04y_zX4_pE&autoplay=1. All the parts can be printed without supports. Parts susceptable to warping have tear-off flanges that minimise this possibility. Use a sponge material in the filter blocks that is elastic when dry; a 2cm cube is perfect. Slit it down the middle about 80% of the way through and pop it in slit outwards. Flexed filament will then drop right in and "lock" itself into the middle.

author: Tobi97l

print_settings.Notes:: Print both files in the given orientation for good structural integrity and overhangs!

description.text:
Info: Detailed assembly instructions coming soon.

What is Project ShadowPiercer?

Project ShadowPiercer is an affordable, partially 3D-printable night vision device. It is designed to be mounted on a "Rhino" helmet mount, so it can be used but also stowed away easily. The core part is a "Mullard XX1306" Generation 2 image intensifier tube.

What does partially 3D-printable mean?

To be affordable, the device consists of many commercially available parts that won't fit together out of the box. So it utilizes a custom 3D-printed shell which allows for easy drop-in-assembly. All you need is some screws, nuts and a soldering iron.

What can it be used for?

Originally, the device was developed to circumvent the high prices or low performance of commercially available night vision devices that put night fighting capabilities far out of reach for the average Airsoft player. But there are many other uses, like night hunting or hiking.

What are the downsides?

Project ShadowPiercer was never intended to be highly durable or very lightweight. While it is light enough to be carried on top of a helmet without getting a sore neck and tough enough to survive a fall, it won't survive worse impacts and might restrict quick head movement in heated CQB situations.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:
  • Print ShadowpiercerV30_Mount.stl with 100% infill.
  • Print ShadowpiercerV30.stl with 20% infill for a faster print or 100% for toughness.
  • Print both files with the lowest humanly possible layer height your printer can manage.

Print both files in the given orientation for good structural integrity and overhangs!

What you need
  • The three prints
  • A helmet with a Rhino Mount
  • 1x Mullard XX1306 Gen. 2 Image Intensifier
  • 1x this watchmaker loupe
  • 1x C-Mount Camera Lens
  • 1x this DC-DC Step Down Buck
  • 1x 2 AA battery box with switch
  • 1x sheet of 1mm Aluminum
  • 1x long M3 screw thread
  • M3 nuts and washers
  • 2x M3 18mm+ screw
  • 1x thin dual wire
  • duck tape
  • zip ties

Note: The focal length of the lens determines your field of view and magnification when looking through the device. The watchmaker loupe has a focal length of 25mm, so when you use a 25mm lens, your magnification will be around 1x. If you decide to use a lens with longer focal length, your field of view will decrease while your magnification increases. So, a 50mm lens will give you 2x magnification.

Note: The image intensifier can be purchased here. This store is small and obviously a little overwhelmed with the online ordering process. After paying them, give them a call and ask for your product to be shipped. Please be nice to them.

Tools required
  • sandpaper
  • metal saw (or similar)
  • soldering iron
  • heavy-duty scissors
  • 6mm hex nut driver
  • multimeter
How to assemble
  • Post-process the prints.Thoroughly remove all support structures and sand down inconsistencies.
  • Optional: Superglue the loupe into the slot on one of the shell halves. You can skip this, but assembling the device will be easier and require only two hands.
  • Configure the step down buck to output exactly 2.6V using the multimeter.
  • Drop the step down buck into the respective box. Plug in both plugs and lead both dual cables out of one of the two holes. The "IN" cable should go out the hole on the side, the "OUT" cable should go out the hole on the front.
  • Cut out a small aluminium piece that exactly fits ontop of the box for the buck.
  • Cut out two 4mm x 20mm aluminum pieces.
  • Punch a small hole into one end of both aluminium pieces.
  • Push the two aluminium pieces into the two slots on the shell. The ends without the holes should stick out about 3mm on the inner side.
  • Bend the short inner ends of the aluminum pieces by 45 degrees.
  • Bend the long outer ends of the aluminium pieces by 90 degrees.
  • Attach the two output cables to the holes of the aluminium pieces. Add some soldering tin to secure them. Be careful with polarity.
  • Push the intensifier tube into the shell with the contacts. The contacts should be pushed out a little. Secure them with zip ties, so there is always pressure on the contacts.
  • Attach the second part of the shell and secure the assembly using cuts of the screw thread with nuts and washers.
  • Screw in the camera lens. Don't put too much force on it.
  • Solder the input wires to a 20 cm piece of dual wire.
  • Solder the dual wire to the battery box. Be careful with polarity.
  • Replace the similar looking piece on the Rhino mount with the mount piece.
  • Attach the device to the mount piece and secure it using the two M3 screws. You might not even need nuts to secure the screws.
  • Put some duct tape on the contacts to keep them from getting wet.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Bike cupholder for takeaway coffee. Affixes to frame on bottle cage mounts.

description.text:
There are a wealth of handlebar mounted coffee cup holders on here so I have designed one that mounts to the frame on the bottle cage mounts. Particularly good for hipster steel frames.

The angle of the holder is designed for touring / hybrid bike geometry. However it's not far off road or leisure MTB angles, so should be pretty compatible.

The circular holder is designed around a UK size16oz cup. I have tested with 16 and 20oz cups and it works well. Due to the cup profiles it should work with most commercially available paper coffee cups.

If you want to transport your coffe this way and keep dry legs:

(1) avoid bumpy roads;
(2) don't overfill your coffee; or
(3) consider double-lidding... 2 lids with one rotated 180 degrees to close off the drinking hole.

My favourite method is (3). If the lids have a shape that prevents 180 degree rotation, get creative. Push any dimples / recesses upwards on the top lid and you should be good to ride.

Print with the circular holder down against the bed and enjoy my caffiene addicted friends.

Please post photos of your makes - Its cool to see what you print + I like to learn how people's print settings affect my designs.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm (print for speed!)

Infill:

50 or 60%

Notes:

Print with the circular holder down against the bed. The bracket should point upwards.

The angle is low so no support is required.

Print in low res for speed (0.2, 0.3mm layers). PLA or ABS should work. Mine is PLA.

title: Wanhao i3 control box bracket (requires frame drilling)

description.text:
Designed to allow you to mount the control box to the right hand side of your printer frame. Stops it being all annoying and hard to carry.

To fit simply drill 2x holes in your frame (check your hardware clears the z axis moving parts). Ignore the MASSIVE holes in my picture - a littel confusion between radius and diameter! they are 5mm in the .stl file supplied.

I have designed it to fix onto control box via the factory holes for the spool holder (I have these on my v1 duplicator).

I've updated the thing file on 5 3 17 to add a small notch that allows the frame to clear the SD/USB plastic surround. This makes installation easier.

Please post photos of your makes - Its cool to see what you print + I like to learn how people's print settings affect my designs.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is another way of solving the problem of the x-axis belt rubbing against the bearing housings of the Wanhao di3. The concept relies on two home-made "rollers" used to push the upper part of the x-axis belt that tiny bit required not to rub against the housings, while at the same time reduces wear on the belt which is now in contact with a rolling, not a sliding surface
This approach is less intrusive than the one involving trimming of the upper bearing housings with a hacksaw in order to increase clearance from the x-axis belt, but there are some things to consider (see further down).
You will need 2 of each:
The .stl file,
M4x30 bolt and nut,
nail about 1.2mm diameter and 23mm long,
18mm of plastic tubing 1.3mm inner diameter. (For this last item, I cut away the tubing of an ordinary used ballpoint pen...)
Assembly:
Print two spacers, pass the nails through the plastic tubing and snap them in place on the spacers as shown in the pictures. The plastic tube should be rotating freely round the nails. Then, put the spacers at the two ends of the upper housing blocks, aligning the openings with the lower, outer holes on the blocks. Tighten in place using the M4 screws or equivalent - see further below.
You should end with the upper part of the belt touching the freshly added rollers, just 1-2mm below the bearing housing. Move the extruder assembly back and forth with your hands, the belts should move freely now without touching the bearing blocks and the ballpoint pen rollers should be rotating along, driven by the belt movement.

And now for the fine print:

  1. I noticed that the spring tensioner of the x-xis belt was installed spring-up, reducing the clearance between the upper and lower parts of the belt, so I reinstalled it upside-down. This gave me some 2mm of clearance between the moving belts....
  2. The spacers need to be secured (i.e.bolted) tight so that they can maintain the distance from the bearing housing during operation. I chose to use two M4 bolts through the lower outer threaded holes of the housings. The hard part was to extend the thread throughout the housing width using the right die, but it worked out fine without taking the extruder asssembly apart. Mind you, you need to make careful, slow and patient moves in order to avoid breaking, snapping or displacing something. Also, it would seem better to keep the extruder closer to the end of the rods, where they are stiffer and can withstand more pressure (when turning the die). Of course, you can save yourself the effort if you can use M3.5 or M3 screws, which should go through the existing holes without messing with the existing - partial - thread (only thought of this just now)

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Since the parts are rather small, neither the resolution nor the infill make much difference.
Printed in PLA.
Check the clearance between the belt and the block

Although I 've been using the pronter for more than a year, I only realized that the belt was rubbing against the housing several months later, after I saw a video with various mods on youtube!!!! (Thank you for letting me see that...)
However, I didn't want to tear half my printer apart nor I fancied the idea of sawing off the bearing housings with a hacksaw...
Then I thought that if i couldn't remove some material from the housings, I could push the belt down and let it slide on a roller in order to minimize friction. That's were the nails and ballpoint tubing came handy.

It's easy to built, takes about 20 minutes to print and another 10 to assemble and it works.

Designed in FreeCad, sliced with Simplify3D and printed at home during a lazy Saturday afternoon...

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a filament filter designed to wipe dust off the filament before it enters the extruder. This filter is able to be put on and taken off without having to remove the filament from the extruder. You will need to print 2 caps and 2 case halves. To assemble it line the cases up with each other so they form a cylinder place one cap on the bottom and one on the top. There are two grooves on each cap this is if you want to use a rubber band to hold them in place. (see picture) You can fill the filter with anything that will wipe the filament as it goes through.

description.text:
German below

DJI Phantom 4 camera lens cover

This beautifully designed lens cover is for the 4K main camera of DJI Phantom 4 drone. It fits perfectly and, thanks to its rounded corners it can also cause scratches nowhere.

Inside is also a small spacer ring available for the glass ensures that the do not directly come into contact with the lens cap and thus prevents scratches by own fault. Many others are not aware of the PLA and ABS printed objects may well have put sharp. The ribbing on the outer housing also provides a secure feeling when and stake out.

You can also cover the cover in our online shop http://www.drohnenshop-berlin.de/DJI-phantom-4-camera-lens-cover

More about the drones fly you get on my German-speaking side under http://www.BerlinerARdrone.de and on YouTube at http://www.youtube.com/BerlinerARdrone.

DJI Phantom 4 Linsenabdeckung

Diese Formschöne Linsenabdeckung ist für die 4K Hauptkamera der DJI Phantom 4 Drohne. Sie passt hervorragend an die Kamera Einheit und dank ihrer abgerundeten Ecken kann sie auch Nirgendwo Kratzer verursachen.

Im inneren ist ebenfalls ein kleiner Abstandsring vorhanden der dafür sorgt das dass Glas nicht direkt mit der Linsenabdeckung in Berührung kommt und somit Kratzer durch Eigenverschulden vorbeugt. Viele User berücksichtigen nicht, das auch PLA und ABS gedruckte Objekte durchaus scharfe stellen haben können. Die Riffelung am Gehäuse äußeren bietet zusätzlich ein sicheres Gefühl beim auf und ab stecken.

Die Abdeckung können Sie auch bei uns im Onlineshop fertig gedruckt Kaufen http://www.drohnenshop-berlin.de/DJI-Phantom-3-Kamera-Schutzabdeckung

Mehr über das Drohnen Fliegen bekommt ihr auf meiner Deutschsprachigen Seite unter http://www.BerlinerARdrone.de sowie bei Youtube unter http://www.youtube.com/BerlinerARdrone

title: Sewing Machine Thread Oiler (BERNINA) updated
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Attatch it onto your sewing machine (i used 2-sided adhesive tape) right into the thread line
Put a folded stripe of felt or foam into it.
Soak it with silicone oil.
Let the threat walk right through the middle.

hint: place it where you can bypass this thing when not willing to oil the threat.

I did a version 2 with a bypass grove because the thread got stuck underneath the oiler when bypassing it.
Now you just put the thread in the bypass grove when not oiling it. That is the case in most of circumstances.

title: 1/4 inch hex to 3/8inch socket adaptor v1

description.text:
Simple adaptor to allow use of 3/8" sockets with 1/4" hex drivers. For light duty use (its plastic!!).

Print with lots of infill for strength (I snapped a 20% infill version today getting a screw out of a fence).

There may be a way to make these stronger. Making the 1/4 inch hex part female with a larger diameter (similar to 3/4 inch diameter). It can then be driven by a 1/4" hex bar (or long screwdriverr bit). That will be v2.

So far my v1 version has stood up to light duty tasks such as doing up and removing fastners.

Please post photos of your makes - Its cool to see what you print + I like to learn how people's print settings affect my designs.

description.text: For hanging your headphones off the bottom of a glass top desk.  Glass should be 8mm thick.  Clips on very securely, won't wiggle off accidentally.

There are two STLs - one with straight corners, one rounded.  I prefer the rounded corners.  
The clip has a rounded entry point and takes a little force to get it on the glass - I found rocking it back and forth allowed it to slip on without too much issue.  
I printed with 3 shells and %25 infill in PLA and it is very strong with very little flex.  Zero worries about it breaking.

print_settings.Notes:: For best results, print in red PLA or ABS.

I have printed it three times, with this being the best print I've gotten so far. I need to print a fan shroud, I think. Anyway, I thought I'd share this with y'all. These are a series of buttons made out of wood/plastic. The original circle shape remains but instead of having two or four holes they have many different ones, square, triangle etc.
You can chose in which holes you want the thread to go, so to sew them on as you like. Materials:
Piece of MDF/plastic (3.00 mm thickness)
220x220 mm.

For the wood, chose one that is solid enough -pine or plywood are too soft- it is better to use MDF, so you can sew it on strongly. Download the .svg file and edit it as you like in Inkscape or Illustrator.
The geometrical forms can be replaced by organic or figurative ones, they can remain abstract as well. You can also change the size of the buttons.
If you want to add some engravings, color the shapes in green. Important : Spaces between holes have to be at least 0.7 millimiters thickness, so the button doesn't break. If you make them smaller than those in the file, remove some holes. Settings for the laser cutter
Wood : power: 100 % speed: 0.7
Plastic : power 100% speed 0.2

Added two new longer arms. an 80mm and 100mm arm to extend the distance of t he camera from the bed. I personally prefer the 100mm as it gives a very clear view of the whole bed.

comments.text: The reason that the camera back isn't staying on is because there are two important little nubs that are in the original camera back, but not present on the remixed version. Print a new back from the original files (not this remixed version) and you should be good to go. Also, the Raspberry Pie Camera V2 will fit in a lot better if you take a small round file and file the inner side of the back where part of the board components are making contact with the back of the case. This is a flaw in the original file and the remixed version.

title: Lulzbot Taz Y Belt Tensioning System

description.text:
As with the x-axis, I found the adjustment/clamping mechanism for the y belt to be a bit of a pain as well. Requires:
11x 3.8mm M3x0.5 threaded heatset inserts (10 for t-track/sliders, one for endstop actuator)
6x M3 x 10mm socket head cap screws (4 for clamps, 2 for set screws which hold sliders in place on t-track)
3x M3 x 6mm socket head cap screws (to mount t-track)
1x M3 x 50mm socket head cap screw (for adjustment)
7x M3 washers (clamps, t-track mounting screws) Don't forget that you will need the endstop actuator if you replace the original y belt mount. To adjust, loosen the set screw on each slider. Adjust tension using the 50mm screw, then re-tighten set screws to lock everything in position.
Print at high (90-95%) infill for robust parts. Mine were made in ABS at 0.20mm layer height with 1 perimeter and 4 top and bottom shells, 95% infill.

title: Syma X8 Re-imagined as a Fire Wheel 450!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Since the parts for the Syma X8 are plentiful as well as cheap, I decide to re-imagined the Syma X8 as a DJI Fire Wheel 450! While I do have this flying, it still is a bit of work in progress and this is remix of many parts which I have found on Thingiverse and I have tried to give them credit for their hard work and listing them in the remix!

Main Syma X8 Parts List:
Syma X8 Complete Motor Assembly: http://amzn.to/2mT0lVP
Syma X8 Prop Kit: http://amzn.to/2m7Yhtg
Syma X8 2000 mah batterys and charger: http://amzn.to/2mGCJHh
Syma X8 Hover Board Receiver: http://amzn.to/2m7RfEE
Syma X8 Transmitter (hover version): http://amzn.to/2msfBvz
Syma X8 screw set: http://amzn.to/2mGCMCU

Build Note: while the stock Syma X8 (motor) shaft housing can screwed to the 3D printed motor adapters with the self taping screws (from here: http://amzn.to/2mGCMCU). it is recommended to either use a #2 bolt & nut combo to positively attach the two or drill it out and use M3 bolt and nut combo (on the back center opening). It is also possible to epoxy the center shaft of the housing to the 3d printed housing for additional support as other wise there is the risk the Syma X8 shaft housings will separate from the 3D printed adapters in flight.

Note 03/12/2017 - Also see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2140188 as I have added a newer (v2) motor mount.

General Note: Construction and use of this model is at your own risk with no warranties made or implied and always fly safe and never over people...

description.text:
A rotating Deathly Hallows pendant, based on ecken's excellent design, but modified to be able to print without supports. The differences between theirs and mine are a larger hole for the finding or chain, and the central post now continues in the center of the ring. This allows you to bridge the spinner post without worrying about any supports.

Designed in Fusion 360 from scratch using my calipers and a printed version of the original.

Printed on my MP Maker Select using Foxsmart PLA. White and copperfill worked fine.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Notes:

I've printed this at both 20% and 100%. I used a raft, because I'm lazy, but it should print fine without one.
